division-node-1.title: Understanding Division as Fractions
learningFocus: Understanding that division can be expressed as a fraction
Express 1 ÷ n as 1/n
Connect fractions to fair sharing scenarios
Identify numerator (what's shared) and denominator (number of sharers)

exemplarProblems.problemText: 1 pizza is shared equally among 3 children. What fraction of the pizza does each child get?
If 1 cake is divided equally among 5 friends, what fraction does each friend get?

questionTypes: X is shared equally among Y people. What fraction does each person get?
Express 1 ÷ n as a fraction.
Write 1 ÷ n as a fraction.
If 1 item is divided equally among n people, what fraction does each person get?

parameters.caption: The circle shows 1 whole divided into equal parts. Each part represents one share.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
Use fractionCircle to visualize the division - it helps students see fair sharing
CRITICAL: Set denominator to match the number of people sharing
Always set numerator to 1 for this section (1 ÷ n problems)
Use age-appropriate contexts: pizza, cake, chocolate, pie
Vary the divisor between 2 and 10
For 'Express as fraction' questions, OMIT mathTool (pure notation exercise)
For sharing context questions, INCLUDE mathTool to visualize the division

division-node-2.title: Dividing Multiple Items Equally
learningFocus: Express m ÷ n as m/n
Visualize sharing multiple items among multiple people
Understand proper fractions result when items < people
Simplify fractions to lowest terms when possible

exemplarProblems.problemText: 2 pizzas are shared equally among 3 children. What fraction of a pizza does each child get?
4 chocolate bars are shared equally among 6 friends. What fraction does each friend get? Give your answer in simplest form.

questionTypes: X items are shared equally among Y people. What fraction does each person get?
Express m ÷ n as a fraction.
Write m ÷ n as a fraction in simplest form.

parameters.caption: Each bar shows one whole. The shaded parts show each person's share.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
Use fractionBar to show multiple items being divided
For questions requiring simplification, explicitly ask for 'simplest form'
CRITICAL: When simplification is required, ensure the fraction CAN be simplified
Use the simplificationPairs to ensure mathematically correct simplified answers
Vary contexts: pizza, cake, chocolate, pie
For pure notation questions (Express X ÷ Y), OMIT mathTool
Ensure numerator < denominator for proper fractions in this section

division-node-3.title: Improper Fractions and Mixed Numbers
learningFocus: Recognize when division results in improper fraction (numerator > denominator)
Convert division to improper fraction
Convert improper fraction to mixed number
Visualize sharing when items exceed number of people

exemplarProblems.problemText: 5 cakes are shared equally among 4 children. How much cake does each child get? Express your answer as a mixed number.
11 pizzas are shared equally among 5 friends. How many pizzas does each friend get?

questionTypes: X items are shared equally among Y people. Express as a mixed number.
Express m ÷ n as a mixed number.
Convert m/n to a mixed number.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - students should calculate mentally/on paper
CRITICAL: Use the exact divisionPairs to ensure correct mixed number answers
Ensure numerator > denominator (improper fraction)
For conversion questions, give the improper fraction; for word problems, give the division
Always ask for mixed number format in the answer
Conversion method: divide numerator by denominator, quotient = whole, remainder = new numerator
Use format 'X Y/Z' for mixed numbers (e.g., 2 1/3)

division-node-4.title: Word Problems: Division as Fractions
learningFocus: Identify division situations in real-world word problems
Set up correct fraction from word problem context
Express answer in simplest form or as mixed number
Include appropriate units in answers

exemplarProblems.problemText: 4 pizzas are shared equally among 7 children. What fraction of a pizza does each child get?
Liz has 7 metres of string. She cuts it into 4 equal pieces. What is the length of each piece?
6 litres of water is poured equally into 8 flasks. How much water is in each flask? Give your answer in simplest form.
13 chocolate bars are shared equally among 5 children. How many chocolate bars does each child get?
A ribbon is 9 metres long. It is cut into 6 equal pieces. What is the length of each piece?

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - word problem solving exercise
CRITICAL: Use the exact problem data to ensure correct answers
Include appropriate units in the answer (metres, litres, kg, etc.)
For simplification problems, explicitly ask for 'simplest form'
For mixed number results (items > people), answer should be a mixed number
Vary contexts: rope/ribbon cutting, liquid pouring, food sharing, weight division
Ensure problems are age-appropriate and realistic for Primary 5 students

decimals-node-1.title: Tenths and Hundredths as Decimals
learningFocus: Convert fractions with denominator 10 to decimals
Convert fractions with denominator 100 to decimals
Understand tenths and hundredths place values
Use place value chart for conversions

questionTypes: Express X/10 as a decimal.
Express X/100 as a decimal.
Convert X/10 to a decimal.
Write X/100 as a decimal.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - would reveal the answer
CRITICAL: For single-digit numerators with denominator 100, answer must have leading zero (3/100 = 0.03, NOT 0.3)
Use the exact fraction-decimal pairs provided to ensure correct answers
Mix questions with denominator 10 and denominator 100
Emphasize place value: tenths = 1 decimal place, hundredths = 2 decimal places
For denominator 10: numerator goes in tenths place
For denominator 100: numerator spans tenths and hundredths places

decimals-node-2.title: Using Equivalent Fractions
learningFocus: Find equivalent fractions with denominators 10 or 100
Convert fractions to decimals using equivalent fractions method
Recognize common fraction-decimal equivalents
Multiply both numerator and denominator by same number

questionTypes: Express X/Y as a decimal.
Convert X/Y to a decimal.
Write X/Y as a decimal.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - students should calculate the equivalent fraction
CRITICAL: Only use fractions that can be converted to denominators 10 or 100
Use the exact fraction-decimal pairs provided to ensure correct answers
Denominators that work: 2, 4, 5, 10, 20, 25, 50, 100
Students should find what to multiply denominator by to get 10 or 100
Then multiply numerator by the same number
Include common fractions: 1/2, 1/4, 3/4, 1/5, 2/5, 3/5, 4/5

decimals-node-3.title: Using Long Division
learningFocus: Set up long division for fraction to decimal conversion
Add decimal point and zeros as needed
Perform long division correctly
Convert both proper and improper fractions to decimals

exemplarProblems.problemText: Express 3/5 as a decimal using division.

questionTypes: Express X/Y as a decimal using division.
Convert X/Y to a decimal.
Use long division to express X/Y as a decimal.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - students should perform long division
CRITICAL: Only use fractions that produce TERMINATING decimals (no repeating)
Use the exact fraction-decimal pairs provided
Denominators that give terminating decimals: 2, 4, 5, 8, 10, 16, 20, 25, 40, 50
Include both proper fractions (result < 1) and improper fractions (result > 1)
Division method: numerator ÷ denominator with decimal point and zeros as needed
Answers should be exact (no rounding needed for terminating decimals)

decimals-node-4.title: Rounding Decimals
learningFocus: Recognize when fractions produce repeating decimals
Round decimals to 1 decimal place
Round decimals to 2 decimal places
Use appropriate notation (≈) for rounded values

exemplarProblems.problemText: Express 5/6 as a decimal correct to 2 decimal places.
Express 2/3 as a decimal correct to 1 decimal place.
Convert 1/3 to a decimal correct to 2 decimal places.
Express 17/6 as a decimal correct to 2 decimal places.
Express 5/9 as a decimal correct to 1 decimal place.

questionTypes: Express X/Y as a decimal correct to Z decimal place(s).
Convert X/Y to a decimal correct to Z decimal place(s).
Write X/Y as a decimal rounded to Z decimal place(s).

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE #1: Generate ONE question per problem
DO NOT include mathTool - students should perform division and rounding
CRITICAL: Use the exact roundingProblems data to ensure correct rounded answers
Only use fractions that produce REPEATING decimals (require rounding)
Denominators that give repeating decimals: 3, 6, 7, 9, 11, 12, etc.
Explicitly state the number of decimal places required: '1 decimal place' or '2 decimal places'
Rounding rule: look at next digit, 5 or more rounds up, less than 5 rounds down
Include both proper fractions (result < 1) and improper fractions (result > 1)
Mix questions asking for 1 d.p. and 2 d.p.
